Graphical abstract The covalent sulfur fixation and chemisorption of 2,5-DCP with CoNC synergistically inhibit the dissolution and shuttling of polysulfides. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are promising as the next generation energy storage options. However, their wide applications have been technically challenged by the diffusion losses of polysulfides and polysulfide shuttle effect. In this work, the small organic molecules of 2,5-dichloropyrazine (2,5-DCP) were combined with Co-doped carbon (CoNC) flakes to achieve the synergic effect of the covalent and chemical sulfur fixation, so as that the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides in LSBs was greatly enhanced. More specifically, the nucleophilic substitution of the 2,5-DCP additive in the electrolyte with polysulfides formed the CS bonds. Through the further covalent N-Li bonds between the N atoms in 2,5-DCP and polysulfides, sulfur fixation was achieved in the form of solid organosulfur. Meanwhile, the CoNC flakes served as the sulfur cathode to chemically anchor the polysulfides. The interaction mechanism between CoNC/2,5-DCP and polysulfides was explored by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations and in-situ infrared spectroscopy. The results showed that the optimal “with 2,5-DCP” sample-assembled LSB exhibited an initial discharge specific capacity of 1244 mA h g−1 at 0.2C, and a capacity decay rate of 0.053% per cycle was displayed after 800 cycles at 1C. The good cycling stability with a high sulfur-loaded electrode sample suggested that the synergic effect of covalent/chemical sulfur fixation enabled the enhancement of polysulfides immobilization-conversion in LSBs. Keywords Lithium-sulfur battery Covalent sulfur-fixation Chemical sulfur-fixation Electrolyte additive Cycling stability 1 Introduction In our modern society, the convenience of portable electronics requiresenergy storage options with high-power density. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) showed such potential as the next-generation energy storage options with their profiles of the high theoretical energy capacity of 2600 Wh kg−1, low production costs and environmentally friendly [1–3]. In practice, the achievable energy capacities of 400–600 Wh kg−1 outperformed those from the lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Inspired by the concept of employing the porous carbon as the sulfur host material, the global research efforts have been directed to enhance the specific energy capacity of the assembled LSBs [4]. The progress informed that the fast capacity fading and poor cycling stability of the assembled LSBs were mainly caused by the diffusion and the shuttle effect of polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) [5]. In literature, the transition metals or their compounds-loaded porous carbon materials have shown the promise to chemically bond and catalyze the conversion of Li2S x , as a result, the diffusion and the shuttle effect of polysulfides were effectively alleviated [6–8]. Guided by those concepts, the diverse sulfur host materials have been developed, and the number of favorable active sites was connected to the factors of composition, dispersion, morphology, crystal structure and interaction with the carbon substrate [9]. For instance, metal particles loaded with the smaller sizes even single metal atoms displayed the larger surface area and more active sites [10–12]. Given the high free surface energy of those metal particles, their loading contents had to be limited to avoid the possible aggregation. It ended up with a limited number of active sites and lacked capacity to alleviate the diffusion and the shuttle effect of polysulfides in LSBs. The recent advances indicated the effectiveness of covalent Li2S x fixation onto the small organic molecules. Depending on the structures of the employed organic small molecules, the mechanisms to fix sulfur and catalyze the conversion of polysulfides differentiated in the experiments. As reported by Fu et al. [13], the diffusion and the shuttle effect of polysulfides were effectively alleviated through covalently fixation sulfur onto the benzenedithiol (BDT) additive in the electrolyte. The results showed that the formed covalent bonds between BDT and bucky paper-loaded sulfur limited the formation of Li2S x products. The capacity retention rate of the optimal electrode sample improved from 69.4% to 84.4% after 200 cycles at the current density of 5C. In contrast, 2,5-dichloro-1,4-benzoquinone (DCBQ) was added into the electrolyte by Chen and co-workers [14]. The assembled LSB cell with S-loaded order mesoporous carbon (CMK-3) as anode displayed an excellent capacity retention rate of 92% after 100 cycles at 0.1C. In the work of Fan et al. [15], O-Li bonds were formed between –OH and polysulfides to fix sulfur and catalyze polysulfide conversion. Zhang et al. [16] and Zhao et al. [17] indicated that the cleavage of Se-Se bonds together with the formation of Se-S bonds accelerated the kinetics of sulfur redox reaction. Zhao and co-workers [18] introduced di-t-butyl disulfide as a redox intermedia. The redox process was promoted by the formed S-Li bonds after the cleavage of SS bonds. More excitingly, diphenyl disulfide (DPDS) was employed by Fu et al. to covalently bond the sulfur atoms released from VS4/CNT material [19]. The assembled LSB cell delivered an enhanced power density of 900 Wh kg−1 (120 mA g−1), and a power density of 440 Wh kg−1 was retained after 300 cycles. Apparently, the covalent and chemical sulfur fixation approaches can be combined to enhance the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides in LSBs. With the potential synergic effects, the target parameters of power density and cycling stability can be met at the same time. So far, few reports have been conducted to probe such synergic effects towards the enhanced LSB performance. In this work, the synergic effects between the 2,5-dichloropyrazine (2,5-DCP) additive in the electrolyte and Co-loaded N-doped carbon (CoNC) flakes as S-host material were demonstrated. Given the polysulfides in LSBs, the solid organosulfur was covalently formed through the nucleophilic substitution of polysulfides by the 2,5-DCP contained in the electrolyte. Meanwhile, the CoNC served as the sulfur cathode to chemically anchor the polysulfides. A such synergic effect from both covalent and chemical sulfur fixation restrained the movement of the polysulfides out of the cathode region. As a result, the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides, transport of Li-ions and reaction dynamics in LSBs were significantly enhanced. In comparison with the LSBs on chemical S-fixation alone, the covalent/chemical sulfur fixation LSBs showed the outperformed capacity, rate performance and cycling stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the CoNC flakes 0.03 mmol of Co(NO3)2 and 1 g of peptone were first dissolved in 10 mL of de-ionized water. The solution was put under ultrasound for 15 min before being freeze-dried. Then, the dried sample was ball-milled with 10 g of NaCl for 3 h. Sequentially, the obtained sample was heated up at 2.5℃ min−1 and maintained at 900℃ for 1 h under N2 atmosphere. Afterward, the collected powder sample was rinsed with de-ionized water and dried to yield CoNC sample. 2.2 Preparation of the electrolyte The mixture of DOL/DME (1:1, v/v) containing 1.0 M bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl)-imide (LiTFSI) and 0.1 M LiNO3 was used as electrolyte. Three parts 2,5-DCP was added into the above electrolyte with its concentration of 30, 40, and 50 mM respectively. 2.3 Preparation of Li2S6@2,5-DCP sample Firstly, Li2S and sublimation sulfur at a molar ratio of 1:5 was added into of DOL/DME (1:1, v/v) solution. The mixture was stirred at 60 ℃ for 24 h to get 0.2 M Li2S6 solution. Then, 10 mg of pyrazine, 10 μL of 2-chloropyrazine and 10 μL of 2,5- dichloropyrazine were added into the 1.5 mL of the prepared Li2S6 solution. After 3 min, the yellow precipitate was collected and rinsed several times with DOL/DME solution. The obtained sample was denoted as Li2S6@2,5-DCP. All the operations were conducted in the glove box with Argon atmosphere. 2.4 Computational modeling Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package VASP [20]. The exchange–correlation function of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was used [21]. The structure of CoNC, 2,5-DCP and CoNC/2,5-DCP were modeled based on the structure of graphene and with 6 × 6 × 1 supercell. A vacuum size of 16 Å was employed to avoid interaction between periodic images. A k-point mesh of 2 × 2 × 1 and a cutoff energy of 500 eV were applied for all the calculations. Both unit cell size and atom coordinates were optimized with a force convergence criterion of 0.001 eV Å−1. To explore the catalytic effect of CoNC/2,5-DCP, Gibbs free energy for S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S conversion was calculated by following the intermediate steps [22]. (1) S8 + * ↔ S8* (2) S8* + 2Li+ + 2e- ↔ Li2S8* (3) Li2S8* + 2Li+ + 2e- ↔ Li2S6* + Li2S2 (4) Li2S6* + 2Li+ + 2e- ↔ Li2S4* + Li2S2 (5) Li2S4* + 2Li+ + 2e- ↔ Li2S2* + Li2S2 (6) Li2S2* + 2Li+ + 2e- ↔ Li2S* + Li2S 3 Results and discussion As reported in the earlier work [23], the used CoNC sulfur host material presents a porous structure and Co nanoparticles are well dispersed within the carbon flakes (Fig. S1). The elemental sulfur was loaded onto CoNC materials by the melt-diffusion approach to obtain the S@CoNC sample. Fig. 1 (a) shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the S@CoNC sample. Apart from the diffraction peaks of carbon material, the rest of the peaks fit very well with the standard of orthorhombic phase ulfur (JCPDS No. 08–0247). This implies the sulfur penetration into the carbon structure [24], and the sulfur content is quantified by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) test in Fig. 1(b) to be 59.54%. As illustrated from the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Fig. 1(c and d), the 3D porous structure remains well after sulfur loading and no obvious aggregation can be observed. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images in Fig. 1(e and f) show the good dispersion of the sulfur grains within the porous structure (circled by the red color). The rich pores within the S@CoNC sample are anticipated to facilitate the mass transport in the electrochemical process (Fig. 1g). The elemental mapping in Fig. 1(h) suggests the good distributions of Co, N and S elements within the S@CoNC sample structure. Considering the important role played by the liquid polysulfides in improving the utilization of active substance and redox reaction kinetics, the optimal amount of 2,5-DCP was found in the experiments only to convert partial polysulfides into solid organosulfurs. The resultant samples went through the evaluations of cycle stability, rate performance and kinetics. Fig. S2 (a) shows the cycling stability curves of “with 2,5-DCP30 mM”, “with 2,5-DCP40 mM” and “with 2,5-DCP50 mM” three sample-assembled LSBs at 0.2C. As seen, the “with 2,5-DCP40 mM” sample-assembled LSB exhibited a high discharge specific capacity of 1244.3 mA h g−1, which can be retained at 760.5 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. The electrochemical performance at multiple rates from 0.1 to 2C is recorded in Fig. S2(c) and Fig. S3. In contrast, the “with 2,5-DCP40 mM” sample-assembled LSB exhibits high discharge specific capacity and excellent kinetic behavior. Besides, a high capacity-retention was displayed when the current density is re-switched to 0.2C. To understand the effect of 2,5-DCP addition on redox kinetics, the CV curves are recorded in Fig. S2(d-f) at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The “with 2,5-DCP40 mM” sample-assembled LSB exhibited a smaller polarization and excellent catalytic performance with a smaller Tafel slope in both reduction and oxidation processes. For ease of discussion, the “with 2,5-DCP40 mM” sample is simply expressed as 2,5-DCP. In comparison with the “without 2,5-DCP” sample in Fig. 2(a), the “with 2,5-DCP” sample-assembled LSB shows a higher discharge specific capacity and better cycle stability. Prior to the 0.2C cycle stability test, the “with 2,5-DCP” sample passed through an activation process at a current density of 0.1C. As illustrated in Fig. 2(b), although there is no shoulder peak appearing at 0.1C at the first discharging cycle at 2.6 V, it appears during charging and remains in the subsequent cycling processes. This is because that LiPSs were generated at around 2.4 V during initial discharge. Sequentially, 2,5-DCP started the nucleophilic substitution rapidly with the generated polysulfides and fixed them covalently. Meanwhile, the 2,5-DCP participated in the catalytic conversion process of polysulfides, as conjectured in Fig. 2(e). Fig. 2(c) shows the partial enlargement of the charge–discharge curve at a current density of 0.2C. It is found that the discharge specific capacity of the “with 2,5-DCP” sample in the first plateau is 394.6 mA h g−1, which is higher than that of the “without 2,5-DCP” sample (308.8 mA h g−1). This indicates that the sulfur utilization rate is higher during the liquid–liquid conversion process. Provided that the onset voltage of the second plateau is related to the nucleation kinetics of solid Li2S2 [25,26], the “with 2,5-DCP” sample displays a smaller conversion overpotential from Li2S4 to Li2S2. Meanwhile, the “with 2,5-DCP” sample shows a smaller activation potential of Li2S in the charging process, and a larger overpotential indicates more precipitation of Li2S in the discharge process [27]. The synergistic catalysis of 2,5-DCP and CoNC for converting soluble LiPSs to solid-state Li2S was investigated by potentiostatic deposition experiments. As shown in Fig. S4, the significant current peaks of “without 2,5-DCP” and “with 2,5-DCP” samples imply the efficient deposition of Li2S. The nucleation capacity of Li2S on the “with 2,5-DCP” sample is 309.5 mA h g−1, which is higher than that of the “without 2,5-DCP” sample (279.7 mA h g−1). In addition, the shorter nucleation time can be translated into a lower LiPSs diffusion and more efficient catalytic conversion [28]. Obviously, the “with 2,5-DCP” sample displays a faster nucleation time compared with that of the “without 2,5-DCP” sample. This suggests that 2,5-DCP improved the catalytic conversion kinetics by promoting the nucleation and precipitation of Li2S. To exclude the capacity contribution of the pyrazine group during the charge–discharge process, the charge–discharge curves of the symmetric battery are recorded in Fig. S5. As understood, the small additional amount of 2,5-DCP will only provide the limited capacity during the charge–discharge process. The high specific capacity and good cycle stability of the “with 2,5-DCP” sample-assembled LSB are mainly attributed to the formation of polysulfides, and sequentially, the 2,5-DCP reacted with polysulfides rapidly through the nucleophilic substitution. The confinement of polysulfides to the cathode side reduced the possible loss of active sulfur. The comparison of the CV curves scanned at 0.1 mV s−1 in Fig. 2(d) shows that 2,5-DCP has a smaller redox potential difference of 241 mV with two well-split oxidation peaks. This implies that 2,5-DCP has a better catalytic effect and faster kinetics on polysulfide conversion of S8 → Li2S. With the understanding that the Co/N atoms in the CoNC host material can catalyze the conversion of polysulfides through chemisorption, the 2,5-DCP additive increased the catalytic activity of CoNC towards the polysulfide conversion. To further understand the reaction mechanism, the interactions between 2,5-DCP and polysulfides were studied with Li2S6 as a reference. As described in Section 2.3, the addition of 2,5-DCP precipitated the yellow product of Li2S6@2,5-DCP, while the addition of pyrazine however did not trigger any precipitation. Judging from the digital photos in Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. S6, the solid organosulfur was covalently formed through the nucleophilic substitution of Cl atoms with S atoms in the electrolyte. The XRD pattern of the Li2S6@2,5-DCP sample in Fig. 3(b) confirms the presence of sulfur crystal phase, the bulge peak at 15°-40° corresponds to the π-π conjugate structure in the benzene ring [29], indicating that the precipitation contains organic sulfur polymer. This result shows that when 2,5-DCP and Li2S6 undergo nucleophilic substitution to form an organosulfur polymer, meanwhile Li2S6 itself undergoes a disproportionation reaction to form elemental sulfur. Meanwhile, the color change of the solution in Fig. 3(a) indicates that a shorter chain polysulfide of Li2S4 is generated. The Raman spectra in Fig. S7 reflect the presence of the SS bonds from S8 (86, 155, 219 and 474 cm−1) [13], and Li2S4/Li2S2 (188, 248, and 439 cm−1) [30,31], respectively. This suggests the disproportionation reaction of Li2S6 with the presence of 2,5-DCP additive. Fig. S8(a) shows the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra of the 2,5-DCP, sublimed sulfur and Li2S6@2,5-DCP samples, respectively. The product is mainly elemental sulfur, and the overtone peaks of six-membered ring skeleton vibration at 1800–1400 cm−1 from the Li2S6@2,5-DCP sample indicate the presence of the 2,5-DCP derivatives. The partial enlargement of the 2,5-DCP sample in Fig. S8(b) shows the absorption peak of the C-Cl bond [32], which however did not appear in the FT-IR spectrum of the Li2S6@2,5-DCP sample. This implies the simultaneous breakage of C-Cl bonds within the 2,5-DCP sample, which can be attributed to the nucleophilic substitution reaction between 2,5-DCP and S6 2-. The visibility of the absorption peak from the CS bond is assumed to be suppressed by the strong sulfur signal. The above results show that Li2S6 is spontaneously disproportionate in the presence of 2,5-DCP, and it can be inferred that 2,5-DCP promotes such a disproportionation reaction. Meanwhile, 2,5-DCP and Li2S6 undergo nucleophilic substitution to form organosulfur polymers. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the Li2S6@2,5-DCP sample in Fig. S9(a) shows the presence of the Li, Cl, C, N, O and S elements. The high-resolution Li 1 s XPS spectra in Fig. 3(c) can be fitted into three peaks of Li-S at 54.8 eV, Li-N at 55.4 eV and Li-Cl at 56.2 eV, respectively [33,34]. Apparently, the Li-S and Li-Cl are derived from Li2S x and the nucleophilic substitution reaction, respectively. This conclusion is further supported by the high-resolution Cl 2p XPS spectra in Fig. S9(b). The Li-N bond is formed by the N atom and Li atom from the 2,5-DCP and Li2S x , respectively, which is confirmed by the signal peak at 398.7 eV from the high-resolution N 1 s XPS spectra in Fig. S9(c) [35,36] . Although the C-Cl bond signal does not present in the high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectra in Fig. 3(d), the CS bond signal appears at 286.1 eV instead. The nucleophilic substitution reaction may occur as illustrated in Fig. 3(f) [14,37]. In the high-resolution S 2p XPS spectra of Fig. 3(e), the peak at 161.5 eV and 162.4 eV belong to Li-S bond and CS bond in ST−1, while peaks at 163.4 eV and 164.5 eV speak belong to SB 0, corresponding SS bond in S8 and SS bond in the organic sulfur polymer. The peaks at 166.7 eV and 167.8 eV represent surface bonded thiosulfate, which is caused by the oxidation of sulfur in polysulfides. The peaks at 169.2 eV and 170.4 eV are attributed to the polythionate complexes, formed primarily by the reaction between polysulfide and the anchored thiosulfate which was used as a medium to promote the conversion of soluble LiPSs to short chain polysulfide [38,39]. The results were consistent with those of the XRD analysis. This observation suggests that the 2,5-DCP additive could effectively catalyze the disproportionation reaction of Li2S6. Again, the nucleophilic substitution reaction between the 2,5-DCP additive and Li2S6 formed the CS and Li-N bonds. Sequentially, reacted with polysulfides into Li2S2/S8, and the derived S8 was further reduced to Li2S x and Li2S2. As such, the catalyzed conversion of polysulfides was effectively achieved by the 2,5-DCP additive. The in-situ FT-IR technique was conducted to probe the effect of the 2,5-DCP additive on the LSB cell charge–discharge processes. Fig. S10 shows the in-situ FT-IR spectra of the two samples “with 2,5-DCP” and “without 2,5-DCP” at 2.8 V. As seen, the CH stretching vibration of unsaturated carbon appears at 3221 cm−1 after 2,5-DCP addition, which attributes to the CH bonds within the pyrazine six-membered ring. Meanwhile, the varied wave numbers of the CC/CN stretching vibrations at 1700–1400 cm−1 together with the varied signal intensity of the CC/CN stretching vibrations were caused by the anode surface products from the substitution reaction of 2,5-DCP additive [40,41]. To verify the interaction between 2,5-DCP and Li2S x , the CH stretching vibration peak at 3220 cm−1 was taken as a reference, because it is not affected by other chemical bonds in the LSB cell system. Fig. S11 compares the in-situ infrared spectra of “without 2,5-DCP” sample under different voltages. As shown, no absorption peak caused by CH bond vibration was detected, and this indicates that the effect of electrolyte decomposition on the CH absorption peak can be ignored. With the potential of 2.8 V as a reference, any changes of the CH stretching vibration peak in Fig. 4 (a anf b) will reflect the specific reaction processes. Bear this in mind, no obvious changes are observed during 2.8–2.4 V. However, the CH stretching vibration peak is noticed to move towards the lower wave numbers at 2.3 V with the increased signal intensity. This attributes to the 1st discharge of LSB cell at 2.3 V and the sequential formation of polysulfides [42]. The 1st discharge plateau supports this observation, and the participation of 2,5-DCP additive induced the changes of the CH stretching vibration peak. By taking Li2S6 as the representative of polysulfides (Fig. 4c), 2,5-DCP reacts with polysulfides through the nucleophilic substitution mechanism, and the breakage of the C-Cl bond generates the CS bonds. On one hand, the weaker electronegativity of S atoms compared to those of Cl atoms will increase the charge densities of the associated C atoms. As a result, the electron cloud density around the six-membered ring increases, which sequentially poses the inductive effect on the neighboring CH bonds. On the other hand, the chemical adsorption occurs between the Li atoms from polysulfides and N atoms from 2,5-DCP. In this process, the electrons flow from Li atoms to N atoms, which increases the electron cloud densities around the six-membered ring and the associated N atoms. Consequently, the strengthened instantaneous dipole moment during vibration increased the CH absorption peak intensity. The inductive effects from the associated C/N atoms decreased the CH bond energy, and the CH stretching vibration peak moved towards the lower wave numbers. It is noticed that the CH stretching vibration peak does not restore back to the initial position at 2.0 V, which may attribute to the deposition of the product onto the anode surface. Correspondingly, the CH bond peak shifts slightly to a high wavenumber after charging, which reflects the conversion of sulfur in the nucleophilic substitution product into active sulfur. During the charging process, the Li+ ions gradually migrate to the anode. Consequently, the electron-donating effect of Li atoms on S atoms gradually weakens, which reduced the corresponding electron cloud density of six-membered rings. As a result, the dipole moment during vibration was reduced and the intensity of the CH absorption peak was weakened. Meanwhile, the increased CH bond energy shifted the peak position to the higher wavenumbers. Compared with the discharge process, the change of the CH peak is smaller during the charging process, which mainly attributes to the generated organosulfur from the nucleophilic substitution between 2,5-DCP and polysulfides as well as the concurrent conversion process from LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S. In other words, the presence of the CS bonds during the entire charging process caused only little influence on the stretching vibration peak of the CH bonds. All those results allow us to conclude that the 2,5-DCP additive participated in the charge–discharge processes through the formation of CS and Li-N bonds. Fig. 5 shows the in-situ FT-IR spectra changes of CN stretching vibration peak at 916 cm−1 at the first discharge–charge process from 2.8 V to 1.7 V. As observed in Fig. 5(a and b), the CN stretching vibration peak of the “without 2,5-DCP” cell does not show the obvious position or intensity changes at 2.8–2.4 V. However, the CN stretching vibration peak is found to move towards the lower wave numbers at 2.3 V with increased signal intensity. The peak was restored back to the initial position after discharging. After the addition of 2,5-DCP, the changes in Fig. 5(c and d) follow the same trend. The interacting mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 5(e). Briefly, the Li atoms from polysulfides and N atoms from the pyridine six-membered ring in carbon material structure formed the chemical adsorption. With the electrons flowing from Li atoms to N atoms, the electron cloud density of the six-membered ring increases, which caused the increasement of the instantaneous dipole moment during vibration as well as the intensity of the absorption peak. As a result, the CN peak moves towards the lower wave numbers along the decreased bonding energy, and restores back to the initial position at 1.7 V. Those results explained the CoNC catalysis effect on the conversion of polysulfides. In addition, the magnitude of the intensity changes of the CN stretching vibration peak in Fig. 5(a-d) decreases after the addition of 2,5-DCP. Taking the chemical environment where the CN bond is located as an example, the substance corresponding to 1.9–2.2 V during the charging process is CNLi-S-Li. The Li+ ions gradually migrate to the anode at 2.3 V in the charging process. When the anode was charging at 2.4–2.8 V, sulfur is mainly deposited on the surface of carbon material in the form of elemental sulfur. During the charging process, the electron-donating effect of Li atoms on N atoms gradually weakens, which reduced the corresponding electron cloud density of nitrogen-containing six-membered rings. Consequently, the dipole moment during vibration was reduced and the intensity of the CN absorption peak was weakened. In contrast, in the charging process of the “with 2,5-DCP” sample, except for the CN bond in the carbon material, CN bond existed in 2,5-DCP as NCSSLi. After the migration of Li+ to the lithium anode, the CN bond existed in the form of NCS8 and the effect of S8 on C did not change much compared to SS bonds. These results further confirmed the synergic effect of 2,5-DCP CoNC in catalyzing the polysulfides conversion process. Further, the DFT calculation was conducted to reveal the interaction between the CoNC/2,5-DCP and polysulfides. Fig. 6 (a) shows the Gibbs free energies of CoNC, 2,5-DCP and CoNC/2,5-DCP during the discharging process of S8 → Li2S. The Gibbs free energy difference of the adjacent LiPSs (ΔG) represents the reaction rate of the conversion step, and the lower ΔG means faster reaction dynamics [43]. In this regard, the lower ΔG value on the CoNC/2,5-DCP sample indicates a favorable step with a faster conversion dynamic compared to other steps. Given the spontaneous reaction from S8 to Li2S2, the positive Gibbs free energy of Li2S2 → Li2S conversion implies it is a rate-determining step, which accounts for the slow sulfur redox reaction [44,45]. Fig. 6(b) displays the optimal adsorption conformation and Gibbs free energy changes of Li2S2/Li2S on samples of CoNC, 2,5-DCP and CoNC/2,5-DCP, respectively. As seen, the free energy of reaction control step on CoNC/2,5-DCP is 0.68 eV, which is lower than those from the other two samples of CoNC (0.9 eV) and 2,5-DCP (0.84 eV). This indicates the synergic effect of CoNC and 2,5-DCP has effectively lowered down the reaction energy barrier from Li2S2 to Li2S and prevented the LiPSs species from moving toward the Li anode region. In other words, the shuttle effect of polysulfides was alleviated effectively, and more supportive data can be found in Fig. S12-14. Fig. 7 (a) shows the effect of 2,5-DCP on the rate performance of the assembled LSBs. At different current densities, the discharge capacity of the cell “with 2,5-DCP” is higher than that of the cell “without 2,5-DCP”. The charge and discharge curves of the cell “without 2,5-DCP” and “with 2,5-DCP” at different current densities are compared, as shown in Fig. S15 and Fig. 7(b), the “with 2,5-DCP”-assembled LSB cell still can maintain the charge–discharge characteristic platform of LSBs at high rates with less polarization effect. The discharge capacities of high and low platforms at different current densities were compared, as shown in Fig. 7(c), the “with 2,5-DCP”-assembled LSB cell showed high discharge capacities, indicating that compared with CoNC only relying on chemisorption, 2,5-DCP and CoNC had more advantages in synergistic interaction. Fig. 7(d) presents the cell “with 2,5-DCP” holds a highly stable coulombic efficiency above 98% during the 800-cycle lifespan with an excellent capacity decay rate of 0.063, and 0.060% per cycle in the first 500, and second 300 cycles, respectively. On average, the capacity decay rate is only 0.053% per cycle for 800 cycles. In judging whether the battery performance is outstanding or not, Table S2 lists the higher capacity and better cycle performance of the cell “with 2,5-DCP” assembled in this work. Meanwhile, it is worth noting that the battery performance hereby is the system-level behavior rather than a component-level property. As aforementioned, the formed nucleophilic substitution and Li-N bonds anchor the polysulfides, alleviate the shuttle effect of polysulfides, improve the sulfur utilization rate and enhance the LSB cycling performance. Lastly, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted to understand the role of 2,5-DCP additive playing in the process of charge transfer [46]. As shown in Fig. S16(a), the “with 2,5-DCP” sample displays a smaller charge transfer resistance 58.4 Ω of at the high frequencies. This indicates the “with 2,5-DCP” sample can support the conversion of polysulfides with a faster reaction dynamic. Meanwhile, the “with 2,5-DCP” sample shows low ion diffusion resistance at low frequencies. Merging with the in-situ FT-IR and XPS results, the effective sulfur-fixation by the “with 2,5-DCP” sample prevents the electrolyte concentration increases by inhibiting the shuttle transfer of polysulfides, so as that the transfer of Li ions is greatly promoted. Fig. S16(b) shows the EIS curves of two samples. Although the charge transfer resistance of the “with 2,5-DCP” sample increased at the high frequencies after 300 cycles at 1C, the EIS curve remained as a semicircle. In contrast, the EIS curve of the “without 2,5-DCP” sample display-two semicircles: one denotes the charge transfer resistance and the other one is related to the inhomogeneous deposition of the Li2S2/Li2S on the electrode surface [47]. Since the conversion of the LiPSs is the key step in studying the reaction dynamics of LSBs. The CV curves of symmetric cells are recorded in Fig. 7(e). In comparison with the case without Li2S6, a clear redox peak is displayed under the test conditions of “without 2,5-DCP” but using Li2S6, which is due to the uniformly dispersed Co atomic clusters can promote the polysulfide conversion. In the presence of 2,5-DCP, the LSB cell exhibits a larger peak current density and a more pronounced redox peak. This indicates that the addition of 2,5-DCP promoted the conversion process of polysulfides catalyzed by CoNC. In addition, symmetric CV curves with scan rates of 30 and 50 mV s−1 are also recorded in Fig. S17, and the cell “with 2,5-DCP” shows better electrocatalytic activity and redox reaction kinetics. The lithium-ion diffusion coefficient between the electrode and the electrolyte was estimated from the CV curves scanned at 0.1–0.5 mV s−1 based on Randles-Sevcik equation below: I p = 2 . 69 × 1 0 5 × n 1 . 5 × A × D Li 0 . 5 × C Li × v 0 . 5 Where I p is the peak current, n is the number of reactive electrons (n = 2), A is the electrode area, and C Li is the Li+ concentration in the electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 7(f-h), the diffusion rates of Li+ in different states were derived from the CV curves scanned at different rates of 0.1–0.5 mV s−1 [48]. The lithium-ion diffusion coefficients of the “without 2,5-DCP” and “with 2,5-DCP” samples at peaks A, B and C are listed in Table S1. The higher Li+ diffusion rates of the “with 2,5-DCP” sample in different states suggest better reaction dynamics. The cyclic stability tests were conducted on 64% S-loaded electrode materials (TGA curve, Fig. S18) under the condition of 2 mg cm−2 and 10 μL mg−1 at 0.2C and 1C to evaluate the practical performance. As illustrated in Fig. 8 (a and b), the electrode sample “with 2,5-DCP” exhibited excellent cycling stability with an initial discharge specific capacity of 844 mA h g−1 at 1C current density, and a capacity retention rate of 79.6% after 200 cycles. The further evaluation in Fig. 8(c) shows that the electrode sample “with 2,5-DCP” exhibited a discharge specific capacity of 677 mA h g−1 after 120 cycles under the condition of 4.3 mg cm−2 and 8 μL mg−1 at 0.2C current density. Those results informed us that 2,5-DCP contributed to the enhancement of polysulfide redox kinetics. Fig. 8(d) shows the digital photos of the lithium anodes and separators after the cycling tests. The “with 2,5-DCP” and “without 2,5-DCP” separator and lithium anode disc samples were disassembled from the individual LSBs and then cleaned with pure DOL/DME solvent. As seen, the surface of the lithium anode and the surface of the separator from the battery “without 2,5-DCP” exhibit black and yellow color, respectively. In contrast, the surface color changes of the lithium anode and the surface of the separator from the battery “with 2,5-DCP” are not significant. Fig. 8(e and f) show the SEM images of Li anode surface. In comparison with the severe pulverization and dendrites of Li anodes cycled in the original electrolyte (Fig. 8e), a relatively flat and smooth surface can be obtained in the presence of 2,5-DCP additive (Fig. 8f). This suggests that the addition of 2,5-DCP was beneficial to inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides, reduce the formation of lithium dendrites, and improve the service life of lithium anodes. Meanwhile, there is no reaction can be observed in Fig. S19, which indicates that 2,5-DCP and metallic lithium foil do not undergo spontaneous chemical reactions. To further verify the effect of 2,5-DCP on lithium deposition/stripping, a Li-Li symmetric battery was assembled, charged and discharged at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and an areal capacity of 1 mA h cm−2. As shown in Fig. S20, the symmetric cell “with 2,5-DCP” exhibits an overpotential of 0.012 V and works stably for more than 400 h. In contrast, the symmetric cell “without 2,5-DCP” displays a serious overpotential, and the battery potential changes significantly after 350 h, which is believed to be caused by the growth of lithium dendrites. This conclusion is consistent with the observations from the SEM image after 0.2C cycling in Fig. 8e. The addition of 2,5-DCP can effectively prevent the growth of lithium dendrites and promote the formation of a dense, uniform, and stable SEI film. 4 Conclusions In this work, the synergic effect of the covalent and chemical sulfur fixation was demonstrated by combining 2,5-DCP additive with CoNC flakes to enhance the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides. Specifically, the solid organosulfur was covalently formed through the nucleophilic substitution of polysulfides by the 2,5-DCP contained in the electrolyte. Meanwhile, the CoNC flakes served as the sulfur cathode to chemically anchor the polysulfides. The interaction mechanism between CoNC/2,5-DCP and polysulfides was explored by the DFT calculations and in-situ infrared spectroscopy. The results suggested that the covalent/chemical sulfur fixation displayed a synergic effect toward the enhancement of polysulfides immobilization-conversion in LSBs. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are promising as the next generation energy storage options. However, their wide applications have been technically challenged by the diffusion losses of polysulfides and polysulfide shuttle effect. In this work, the small organic molecules of 2,5-dichloropyrazine (2,5-DCP) were combined with Co-doped carbon (CoNC) flakes to achieve the synergic effect of the covalent and chemical sulfur fixation, so as that the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides in LSBs was greatly enhanced. More specifically, the nucleophilic substitution of the 2,5-DCP additive in the electrolyte with polysulfides formed the CS bonds. Through the further covalent N-Li bonds between the N atoms in 2,5-DCP and polysulfides, sulfur fixation was achieved in the form of solid organosulfur. Meanwhile, the CoNC flakes served as the sulfur cathode to chemically anchor the polysulfides. The interaction mechanism between CoNC/2,5-DCP and polysulfides was explored by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations and in-situ infrared spectroscopy. The results showed that the optimal “with 2,5-DCP” sample-assembled LSB exhibited an initial discharge specific capacity of 1244 mA h g−1 at 0.2C, and a capacity decay rate of 0.053% per cycle was displayed after 800 cycles at 1C. The good cycling stability with a high sulfur-loaded electrode sample suggested that the synergic effect of covalent/chemical sulfur fixation enabled the enhancement of polysulfides immobilization-conversion in LSBs.

coredata.dc:title: Synergic effect of covalent and chemical sulfur fixation enhancing the immobilization-conversion of polysulfides in lithium-sulfur batteries
